intro: Mentha hirsuta var. cruciata, commonly known as the hairy mint or cruciata mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine hairs, giving it its common name. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pale blue to purple and appear in whorls along the stem. This variety is valued for its medicinal properties and is often used in traditional herbal remedies.
